summary: Agent can control a web browser to test applications, visually edit layouts and styles, audit accessibility, convert designs into code, and more. It has full access to console logs and network traffic.
key_takeaways: Browser capabilities include navigation, clicking, typing, scrolling, screenshots, console output, and network traffic monitoring.
The design sidebar allows modifying your site directly in Cursor with real-time visual adjustments.
Browser state (cookies, localStorage, IndexedDB) persists between Agent sessions based on your workspace.
Browser runs as a secure web view controlled using an MCP server running as an extension.

questions.question: What data persists between browser sessions in Cursor Agent?
questions.explanation: Browser state persists between Agent sessions including cookies, localStorage data, and IndexedDB content. The browser context is isolated per workspace.

questions.question: What does the browser design sidebar in Cursor allow you to do?

options.text: Only view the page source code
Modify your site directly with real-time visual adjustments for position, dimensions, colors, and appearance
Only take screenshots of the page

questions.explanation: The design sidebar provides visual editing controls for position and layout, dimensions, colors including gradients, and appearance like shadows and border radius. Changes can be applied to update your codebase.

questions.question: When using Cursor Browser for accessibility auditing, which prompt would be most effective?

options.text: Check color contrast ratios, verify semantic HTML and ARIA labels, test keyboard navigation, and identify missing alt text

questions.explanation: For accessibility auditing, Agent can check color contrast ratios, verify semantic HTML and ARIA labels, test keyboard navigation, and identify missing alt text to help meet WCAG compliance standards.
